column1: Tychy ([ˈtɨxɨ] (listen); former German: Tichau) is a city in Silesia
column3: approximately 20 kilometres (12 mi) south of Katowice. Situated on the southern edge of the Upper Silesian industrial district
column4: the city borders Katowice to the north
column6: Bieruń to the east and Kobiór to the south. The Gostynia river

column1: Since 1999 Tychy has been located within the Silesian Voivodeship
column2: a province consisting of 71 regional towns and cities. Tychy is also one of the founding cities of the Metropolitan Association of Upper Silesia
column3: a pan-Silesian economic and political union formed with the eventual aim of bringing the most populous Silesian areas under a single administrative body.

column1: Tychy is well known for its brewing industry and its international developed brand Tyskie
column2: which dates back to the 17th century. Since 1950 Tychy has grown rapidly
column3: mainly as a result of post-war socialist planning policies enacted to disperse the population of industrial Upper Silesia.

column1: The moniker Tychy is derived from the Polish word cichy
column2: meaning "quiet" or "still". Although appropriate for most of Tychy's history
column3: the name is now somewhat ironic considering the growth of the city from 1950 onwards.

column1: Originally established as a small agricultural settlement on the medieval trade route between Oświęcim and Mikołów
column2: Tychy was first documented in 1467. In 1629 the first trace of serious economic activity was recorded in the shape of the Książęcy Brewery
column3: which is now one of the largest breweries in Poland.From 1526 onwards the area on which Tychy is built was part of the Austrian Habsburg Monarchy. This situation came to an end when Prussia forcibly took the land in 1742
column4: before itself becoming part of the German Empire between 1871 and 1918. For a short period between 1918 and 1921 Tychy was just inside the border of the newly formed Weimar Republic and still a part of the German Province of Silesia
column5: and on 16–17 August 1919 the Battle of Paprocany (present-day district of Tychy) was fought as one of the first battles of the Silesian Uprisings (1919 to 1921). After the uprisings Tychy was reintegrated with the re-established Polish state.Shortly after its cession to Poland
column6: Tychy began to develop into a small urban settlement
column12: a bowling hall and a number of shops and restaurants. In 1922 it was visited by leader of interwar Poland
column13: Józef Piłsudski. Its population also grew between World War I and World War II
column15: 000 at its highest point during this time.

column1: Along with the rest of industrial Upper Silesia Tychy was occupied by Nazi Germany forces after the invasion of Poland and annexed into the Third Reich
column2: while many of its inhabitants who were not expelled or exterminated were forced to change their nationality to German in order to comply with the racist policies of Nazi Germany. Mass arrests and executions of Polish activists and former Polish insurgents of 1919–1921 were carried out in the first days of the occupation in September 1939. As early as September 3
column4: the Germans murdered several Polish residents of the city
column6: the youngest was 16 years old. The last public execution was carried out on September 22
column8: when five members of the underground Polish resistance movement were killed. Tychy received minimal damage during the invasion because most of the nearby fighting took place in the Mikołów-Wyry area. The E701 working party of the Stalag VIII-B/344 prisoner-of-war camp was located in the present-day Czułów district.Tychy was liberated on January 28

column1: The "New City" was designated by the Polish government in 1950 and deliberately located near to Katowice with the intention that it would not be a self-sustaining city. It was granted town rights in 1951. Tychy is the largest of the so-called "new towns" in Poland and was built from 1950 to 1985
column2: to allow for urban expansion in the southeast of the Upper Silesian industrial region. In the 1950s the neighbourhood Osiedle A was built
column4: and the design and planning of the next neighbourhoods was entrusted to Kazimierz Wejchert and his wife Hanna Adamczewska-Wejchert. In the 1950s
column5: 1960s and 1970s numerous industrial enterprises were created. In 1951 and 1973 the city limits were greatly expanded by including Paprocany and Wilkowyje (in 1951)

column1: In the administrative reforms which came into effect in 1999
column2: Tychy was made a city with the status of a powiat (city county). Between 1999 and 2002
column3: it was also the administrative seat of (but not part of) an entity called Tychy County (powiat tyski)
column4: which is now known as the Bieruń-Lędziny County.

column1: The Tyskie Brewing Museum was founded in 2004
A large Fiat car factory is located in Tychy
column3: and is owned by the Italian manufacturer since 1992. In 2008
column4: the factory had a production of nearly half a million cars. It produces the new Fiat 500 and the new Lancia Ypsilon. It was the exclusive manufacturing site for the second generation Fiat Panda until 2012
column6: and of the 2nd generation Ford Ka (under an OEM agreement between the two manufacturers) until May 2016.

column1: Also in Tychy is located the GM Powertrain Poland factory producing automobile engines for General Motors cars. This plant was opened by Isuzu as Isuzu Motors Polska (ISPOL) in 1996; 2002 GM took over 60% interest of that company
column2: and in 2013 the remaining 40%.The Tyskie beer is produced in Tychy
column4: a subsidiary of the multinational brewing company SABMiller. It is reportedly one of the best selling brands of beer in Poland
column5: with around 18% share of the Polish market as of 2009.

column1: In Tychy operates one of three remaining trolleybus systems in Poland.
Tychy is home to two major sporting teams
column2: both named GKS Tychy. GKS stands for Górniczy Klub Sportowy
column4: which is a common prefix for Polish sports teams situated near mines or in mining regions.

column1: GKS Tychy ice hockey club is among the most successful in Poland and plays in its premier league
column3: the team won the Polish Championships in 2005
column6: 2019 and 2020 and has won the Polish Cup eight times. The club is housed in the newly refurbished Tychy Winter Stadium (Polish: Stadion Zimowy w Tychach)

column1: Several players from the club have gone on to play in the American and Canadian NHL. These include Mariusz Czerkawski and Krzysztof Oliwa.
GKS Tychy football club football club was also established in 1971 and currently plays in the Polish Second League. Throughout a varied career the club reached a pinnacle between 1974 and 1977
column2: making it into top Polish league Ekstraklasa and finishing second in 1976. During those glory days GKS Tychy also participated in the 1976–77 UEFA Cup. It played in the top division again in 1995–1997. Tychy City Stadium (Polish: Stadion Miejski w Tychach) is home to the club and seats 15

column1: A few notable footballers were either born in Tychy or spent some of their career at the club
column2: the most famous being Real Madrid and Poland goalkeeper Jerzy Dudek. Ekstraklasa player Bartosz Karwan started his career there
column3: as did retired player Radosław Gilewicz. Napoli and Poland national team striker Arkadiusz Milik was born in Tychy
column4: as well as former Bayer Leverkusen defender Lukas Sinkiewicz

column1: Tychy hosted several matches of the 2019 FIFA U-20 World Cup.
Tychy is also home to several other sports teams
column2: including basketball team Big Star Tychy
column3: futsal team GKS Jachym Tychy and floorball team TKKF Pionier Tychy.

column1: Tychy has been the birthplace and home of notable people
column2: both past and present. German sculptor August Kiss (1802–1865) was born in Paprotzan
column4: which is now situated within modern day Tychy. Most famous for his grand neoclassical works
column5: Kiss also sculpted the fine pulpit of St. Adalbert's church in Tychy's neighbouring town of Mikołów. Augustyn Dyrda (b. 1926) is a sculptor who currently resides in the city and is best known for his socialist realist and modernist works

column1: Soldier Roman Polko (b. 1962) is one son of Tychy whose achievements hold national importance today. His distinguished career has led him to the post of acting chief in Poland's Bureau of National Security.

column3: lead singer of blues-rock band Dżem
lead singer of pop-rock band Feel
